body.p: The purpose of this activity is to give guided practice at solving problems involving binomial random variables and to teach how the same probabilities can be found using a statistical software package.

A multiple choice test has 10 questions, each with 5 possible answers, only one of which is correct. A student who did not study is absolutely clueless, and therefore uses an independent random guess to answer each of the 10 questions.

p.em: Let X be the number of questions the student gets right.

body.p: Applying the binomial formula is a good way for "first-timers" to understand the mechanics of binomial probabilities. Once you have mastered the technique, however, it may still be tedious to perform the necessary calculations.

For example, if I would ask you: What is the probability that the student will get at most 4 questions right? Or in other words, if we wanted to find P(X ≤ 4), we would need to add P(X = 0) + P(X = 1) + P(X = 2) + P(X = 3) + P(X = 4).

For each of these 5 probabilities, we would need to use the formula, and then add the probabilities. This is very tedious. When calculations involve large n values, calculations become tedious as well. Luckily, any statistical software will do binomial calculations for us.

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: To find probabilities of the type P(X = k) or P(X ≤ k) in R, we'll use the following function:
alternative.code: To find the probability of the type P(X=k) use the following function: dbinom(k, n, p)
To find the probability of the type P(X ≤ k), use the following function: pbinom(k, n, p)
alternative.p: where

ul.li: k is the number of successes in trials
n is the number of independent trials
p is the probability of success in each trial

alternative.p: As practice, follow these steps to find P(X = 4) for our example (where n = 10 and p = 0.2), and verify that you get the same answer as you did in the last question, where you did it by hand.
Now use R to find the probability that the student gets no more than 4 questions right: P(X ≤ 4).

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: To find probabilities of the type P(X = k), P(X < k), P(X ≤ k), P(X > k), or P(X ≥ k) in StatCrunch, we'll use the following:

ul.li: Choose Stat → Calculators → Binomial.
Enter the value for n in the textbox for n.
Enter the value for p in the textbox for p.
Choose the appropriate symbol from the pull-down menu for the probability you want to calculate (either =, >, <, ≤, or ≥).
Enter the value for k in the textbox.
Press Compute.

alternative.p: As practice, follow these steps to find P(X = 4) for our example (where n = 10 and p = 0.2), and verify that you get the same answer as you did in the last question, where you did it by hand. Now use StatCrunch to find the probability that the student gets no more than 4 questions right: P(X ≤ 4).

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: Here is how we'll do this in Minitab:

ol.li: If you would like to find probabilities of the type P(X = k) choose "Probability." If you would like to find probabilities of the type P(X ≤ k) choose "Cumulative Probability."
Enter the value of n next to "Number of trials" and the value of p next to "Event Probability."
Choose "Input constant" and give the value of k.

alternative.p: As practice, follow these steps to find P(X = 4) for our example (where n = 10 and p = 0.2), and verify that you get the same answer as you did in the last question, where you did it by hand.
Now use Minitab to find the probability that the student gets no more than 4 questions right: P(X ≤ 4).

alternative.title: Excel 2007 Instructions
alternative.p: To find probabilities of the type P(X = k) or P(X ≤ k) in Excel, we'll use the following function: =BINOMDIST(k, n, p, cumulative) where

ul.li: k is the number of successes in trials
n is the number of independent trials
p is the probability of success in each trial

cumulative is a logical value that determines the form of the function. If cumulative is TRUE, then BINOMDIST returns the cumulative distribution function, which is the probability that there are at most k successes: P(X ≤ k). If FALSE, it returns the probability mass function, which is the probability that there are exactly k successes: P(X = k).

alternative.p: As practice, follow these steps to find P(X = 4) for our example (where n = 10 and p = .2), and verify that you get the same answer as you did in the last question, where you did it by hand.
Now use Excel to find the probability that the student gets no more than 4 questions right: P(X ≤ 4).

alternative.title: TI Instructions
alternative.p: To find probabilities of the type P(X = k) or P(X ≤ k) using your TI graphing calculator, we'll use the following functions:
To find P(X = k), use binompdf(n, p, k).
To find P(X ≤ k), use binomcdf(n, p, k).
where:

ul.li: n is the number of independent trials
p is the probability of success in each trial
k is the number of successes in trials

alternative.p: binomcdf returns the binomial cumulative density function, which is the probability that there are at most k successes: P(X ≤ k).
To access these functions on your TI graphing calculator:

ul.li: Choose DISTR (2ND/VARS).
Choose A:binompdf(
or choose B:binomcdf(
Then enter the values for trials, p, and x value.
Highlight Paste and press ENTER.
You should see binompdf(n, p, x) with the values you entered. Press ENTER.

Now use your TI to find the probability that the student gets no more than 4 questions right, P(X ≤ 4).

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: Use R to find the probability that the student gets more than 2 questions right, P(X > 2).
Guidance: R will calculate for us only probabilities of the type P(X = k) or P(X ≤ k). To find P(X > 2) think about the complement of this event.
